posts.name:
Nona Prather
Nona Prather
posts.content:
The most successful speakers aren’t just speakers—they’re thought leaders. 

This week, try one of these thought leadership activities:
Write a LinkedIn article sharing industry insights.
Host a live Q&A to connect with your audience.
Collaborate with another expert for a shared post.
Start small, but think big.

comments.commentText: Sharing your expertise is always a good investment! Love this, Nona Prather.
It's also an avenue for growth and improvement.

posts.commentAdded: Great tips! Starting small can lead to impactful connections. Excited to see how we can all elevate our thought leadership together!

posts.name:
Chris DeGasperis
Chris DeGasperis
posts.content:
Just had an insightful conversation with Dana Dunleavy from Kinnelon Design Creative Studio , where she shared some valuable 
hashtag
#branding insights!

Branding goes beyond aesthetics—it's the art of storytelling. Crafting the right message for the right audience can be a game changer. Dana excels at translating big-picture ideas into tangible results, emphasizing the power of connection in both staffing and branding strategies.

 Who is your target audience?
 How do you engage with them?
 What unique value do you offer?

It's always a pleasure connecting with creative minds like Dana, sparking ideas for potential collaborations. Exploring synergies between innovative talents like Dana and professionals in thenetwork and myconnections.

If you have any recent branding or networking tips to share, feel free to join the conversation!
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Branding truly is about storytelling. Excited to explore more ways we can connect and collaborate in this space! #branding

posts.name:
Daren Lauda
Daren Lauda
posts.content:
Withdrawing a promised promotion was one of my career's top five worst professional days.

I promised a promotion to someone. “Achieve these metrics, and we will promote you.”

I was in a big role and didn’t hesitate to commit. Unfortunately, I made a commitment I could not keep.

I thought offering the promotion was within my authority, but I was shocked to learn I was wrong. I let one of my team members down in the worst way.

Something similar happened to me once. I was offered a position with one of the largest software companies in the world.

An SVP presented the offer verbally, and the offer letter was promised to follow within two business days, so my wife and I celebrated with a nice dinner.

The offer letter never came. It seems he didn’t have the authority either.

I learned two painful lessons.

The first is pretty simple: don’t make promises you cannot keep. And when it comes to HR items, dot every i and cross every t before making commitments. Check and double-check.

The second is that holding a title is different from having authority.

In large organizations, authority may be explicit and documented. Still, check and double-check.

In smaller organizations, authority may be fluid, changing based on the business's needs or the founder's opinion. So definitely, check and double-check.
posts.commentAdded: Thank you for sharing your experience! It’s a powerful reminder of the importance of clear communication and understanding authority in the workplace.

posts.name:
Arpit Bhayani
Arpit Bhayani
posts.content:
I have some news to share :) Profile[.]fyi is joining forces with Mercor to help a billion people find their next job 

2024 was the year I took the leap of faith and ventured out with, to build a social network for people in tech, and the idea evolved into what you see today as Profile.

Building an engineering team of 6, thinking of business, making product decisions, and shipping things that matter was quite a task. Listening to customers, understanding market feedback, and operating frugally without any funds was fun.

I keep talking about business >> product >> engineering, and I am so happy that I got to live and breathe that for one year straight; it made me a better and super-practical operator.

I am super happy that I ventured out and even more, to have met and known; seeing him work was a crash course of how seasoned leaders operate.

What next for me? I have joined Google and will work on Ads Forecasting as my full-time responsibility. On the side, I will keep building DiceDB - an open-source in-mem database and putting out a ton of
stuff on my socials and YT channel.

Thank you to everyone who supported us in the journey, it truly means a ton. This was the experience of a lifetime and something I would like to do again.

Once an entrepreneur, always an entrepreneur.

comments.commentText:
Arpit Bhayani Taking a career leap with you was one of the best things I did. Thoroughly enjoyed the rollercoaster ride with you.
You are a diamond in to the tech community.

posts.commentAdded: Congratulations on this exciting new chapter! 🎉 Your journey is truly inspiring — can’t wait to see the impact youll make at Google and with DiceDB!

posts.name:
The Social Media Marketing Group
The Social Media Marketing Group
posts.content:
Think LinkedIn is just for profile updates? Think again. 64% of buyers look for and prefer thought leadership content over boring promotional materials. 63% say it shows you understand their challenges.

Translation: posting great content isn’t optional—it’s table stakes. The same goes for hiring managers, your next investor, or top talent. Whether it’s a sharp take on industry trends or solving real-world problems, your content is your credibility.

Skip the fluff and focus on insights that educate and engage. In a crowded feed, the loudest voice isn’t the winner—the smartest one is. So, what’s your next post going to say about you? I hope this handy-dandy chart helps!
posts.commentAdded: Great reminder! Quality content is key to building credibility. Lets elevate the conversation with insights that truly resonate! 💡

posts.name:
Kaushi Biddappa 🕉
Kaushi Biddappa 🕉
posts.content:
hashtag
#driveclaritywithkau  It is apparent meaningful work does make us happier, and there are hundreds of studies showing that job satisfaction and life satisfaction are positively related.

AND there are so many ways to navigate this space.

Interestingly there are three career models

 ‘Steady State’ careers are those that are associated with one job over decades, where one doesn’t advance much but increases in expertise. This was much more common in the past than it is today. However, it might be right for you if you really love stability and want a job that allows you to spend your life on things you care a lot about outside work.

 'Transitory Career' here the person jumps around all over the place. From the outside it looks chaotic however, it is the profile of someone who loves trying new things, and a moves around based on non-job criteria such as lifestyle, location or social life.

 ‘Spiral’ careers is the last category.  People in this model might make a pretty dramatic career shift every decade or so but there is a method to the madness. They are using their skills and knowledge in one field and applying it to another while getting a variety of experiences for their own fulfilment .

So you might be asking what is the right path for you?
In your heart you probably already know and in general this is the way to know how to proceed along the professional path in your life

Discern how it make you feel.
 Does this opportunity excite you, frighten you or deaden you?

If it excites you a lot and frightens you a little, this is a signal to move forward.
If it simply frightens you, you need a lot more information.
If it deadens you when you imagine doing the new job, the answer is clear : turn it down.

Yes, life is so much simpler when you ask the right questions.

Thank you Oprah and Arthur C Brooks for the wisdom.
'Build the Life You Want'.

is

Your advocate for
in the neighbourhood

comments.commentText:
Steady careers? A rarity today. People who stay loyal to a company for decades, growing with it, are truly admirable.I once met a customer who had been with her company for 19 years. She loved her work that she worked up until her due date for delivery of her first child, thanks to a supportive family & flexible work culture,her career is her “first child,” evolving alongside her personal milestones.

Transitory careers? labeled as chaotic, but they’re anything but. A talented friend of mine worked with a North American, then a German, and finally a UK-based automotive company. With every move, she adapted swiftly, learned on the job, and became an indispensable team member. Switching jobs frequently requires agility, continuous learning, and the ability to tailor your skills to fit each new role.

My own journey has been spiral-type, starting in academia and landing in corporate. Though each field was different, I connected the dots and applied lessons learned in one domain to the next. This path taught me adaptability, resilience, and how to turn every career shift into an opportunity for growth.

No matter the path,steady, transitory, or spiral,the secret is growth, learning, and staying open to new opportunities at every turn.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Choosing the right career path is crucial. Its all about what truly excites and fulfills us. #DriveClarityWithKau
